instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_ONFF_L: What is SMC_ONFF_L? This is a typo of SMC_ONOFF_L When you see SMC_ONFF_L, assume they meant to type SMC_ONOFF_L.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message:
Hello gents. 

Have a weird one. 

Original Issue: Wont power up not was MagSafe light on. corrosion around SMC. Replaced all corroded capacitor and resistors along with SMC chip (due to short seen on Couple of caps). 

Repaired and board now boots up. 

New Weird issue: can?t power up the computer using the power button. However, I can perform SMC reset, power off the computer by holding down on the power button. I power on the computer when MagSafe is connected right after reconnecting battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message: I think I may have figured out what may be wrong. I?ve got 3.4v on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> and 0.4v when power button is pressed. Going to pull the SMC and check for continuity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message: That's normal pressing the power button shorts <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground....have you tried a known good keyboard, trackpad, and trackpad flex???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message: I currently do not have a keyboard/trackpad parts for the model to test with (i checked and ohmed out the ribbon cable from the trackpad to the logic board, just incase there were bridge connections, and it ohmed good). What i'm wondering is, if it was either of these guys, would the power button still respond when i press it to shutdown the computer? Plus from the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> voltage drop when i press the power button, it appears the keyboard may be working as well. Why i was thinking of going for the smc is due to having 3.4v present, which is fed from what i believe is a pull up resistor (<RESISTOR>R5170</RESISTOR>). Since this voltage is present, i'm thinking the trace from that resistor to the smc must have corroded away.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message: Before i pull the smc, i'm curious what the resistance measurement on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> should be. I'm getting about 144K, does that sound about right. Its the exact same measurement i'm getting on a donor board that's missing its smc.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message: Try a KNOWN GOOD trackpad and trackpad flex first do not blindly replace the SMC when it could be something super simple....you NEED to stock these test parts anyways if you are going to do board repair.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message:
"I can perform SMC reset, power off the computer by holding down on the power button"
So SMC receives the power button signal!

Check if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts when you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal, for a short time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message: Weird, so i soldered a test wire to J1800 (<SIGNAL>XDP_CPU_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>) since it was tied to <RESISTOR>R1082</RESISTOR> (0ohms). Power the laptop up to test and now i can't keep it powered off. It just keeps restarting itself after I power down the board. I even unplugged the keyboard and it still powers itself back up after i power it down. I confirmed the wire i installed was bridged across another pad and then also pulled the wire with the same result. I had noticed this issue earlier today but it went away, so thought it was a fluke

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message:
"i soldered a test wire to J1800 (<SIGNAL>XDP_CPU_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>)"
WHAT???
I asked you to do something different.

BTW, I cannot find <RESISTOR>R1082</RESISTOR> on 00164 board; you meant <RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR>, I suppose...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message: Correction, it's <RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR>. <RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR> is a 0ohm resistor with <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> on pad 1 and <SIGNAL>XDP_CPU_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> on pad 2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message:
"Check if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts when you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal, for a short time."
???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message: It consistently reading 3.3v when i trigger the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONFF_L</SIGNAL> signal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message:
So any suggestions? Its reads 3.325v each time i press the power button with no spikes or sudden drop. Plus the board keeps powering itself back up after i hold the power button long enough for it to shutdown. 

After allowing it to bootup completely into OS, and then shut it down, it now stays shutoff and the power button doesn't respond unless i unplug and plug the MagSafe before the board powers up again. Also, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> still remains at 3.3v when i attempted to power it back up with the power button this time around.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message:
Now try triggering <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> instead.
Board should start.
Touch the ground with previously wire soldered on <RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR> for that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message: Yep the board starts and i can also shut it down with the same wire to ground and it stays shutdown after i take the wire off ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message:
Yeah, with charger.
Test now if is possible on battery alone, no charger...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message: Not powering up with battery only.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message:
Normal, because SMC is not informed about pressing power button.
You issue is SMC related.
Normally should change the SSMC and check if all its pad are OK.
Another trick is soldering a diode with the anode on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> and cathode on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
Just for test, I'm not sure if timing requirement for power on is OK in this case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Wont power up when pwr button pressed
threads.message: Replaced the SMC again and its fixed. Once again, you've been awesome and very helpful. Thanks a ton.
